questions.question: Question 1: The life cycle given below is of which of the following:
questions.explanation:
The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica. Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are 
seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no 
animal reservoir. The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic 
epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break 
down to form flask-shaped ulcer. The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the 
feces. Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external 
environment and are responsible for transmission. The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver. Note: The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, 
E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be 
non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed to have amoebic dysentery. Which of the following is the 
infective form of the protozoan causing this disease?
questions.explanation:
The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebic 
dysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days. The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica: The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. The 
nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel 
appearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility. The below image shows trophozoite form. 518 
Sold by @itachibot The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cyst 
wall to become a cyst. The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear. The below image shows cystic form.

questions.question:
Question 3: 505 
Sold by @itachibot A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal pain and 6 episodes of passing 
foul-smelling dark stool mixed with mucus and blood streaks. There is no history of fever and 
tenesmus. On examination, vitals are stable and localized tenderness is present in the right 
iliac fossa. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amoebic dysentery and the causative agent is 
Entamoeba histolytica. Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis: • Acute intestinal amebiasis- dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. 519 
Sold by @itachibot • Chronic amebiasis- low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. • The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The 
ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the 
ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the 
colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole. Option A - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull 
epigastric pain, and flatulence. Option C - Campylobacter presents with fever, pain, and watery diarrhea. The stool contains 
leucocytes and blood. Option D - Shigella causes bacillary dysentery which is characterised by fever and generalised 
abdominal tenderness.

questions.question:
Question 4: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab. 
On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you will 
expect to see in this stool sample?

options.a: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux

questions.explanation:
The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in the 
stool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The other 
stool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals. The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only 
characteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from the 
nonpathogenic entamoeba. Amoebic dysentery: Clinically, it is insidious in onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, and 
fever are absent. Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals and 
eosinophils are present. Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen in 
stool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils. The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals: 520 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with abdominal pain and mucus in stool is diagnosed to have intestinal amoebiasis. 
Which of the following is the most common extraintestinal complication of this disease? 506 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common extraintestinal complication of amoebiasis is hepatic amoebiasis. In intestinal amoebiasis, most of the trophozoites reach the liver. However, only a small portion of 
them actually lodge and multiply in the liver cells. Patients usually present with an enlarged, 
tender liver without detectable impairment of liver function called amoebic hepatitis. Few patients go on to develop amoebic liver abscess. The center of the abscess contains thick 
chocolate brown pus (anchovy sauce pus), which is made up of liquefied necrotic liver tissue. It is 
bacteriologically sterile and free of amoeba. The periphery is made up of nearly normal liver tissue 
containing invading amoeba. Complications and sequelae of intestinal amoebiasis: • Fulminant amoebic colitis • Toxic megacolon • Perianal ulceration • Amoeboma • Extraintestinal amoebiasis • Hepatic amoebiasis (most common)- Amoebic hepatitis and Amoebic liver abscess • Amoebic appendicitis and peritonitis • Pulmonary amoebiasis • Cerebral amoebiasis • Splenic abscess • Cutaneous amoebiasis • Genitourinary amoebiasis 521 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 40-year-old man was brought to the casualty with complaints of nausea, vomiting and 
disorientation. His brother tells you they had recently gone on a camping trip where they had 
swum in a freshwater lake. On examination, Kernig's sign is positive. A spinal tap is 
performed and the findings of CSF wet mount microscopy are shown below. Which of the 
following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing amoeboid trophozoite form with pseudopodia 
is suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It is caused by Naegleria fowleri. It is also known as brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite and 
flagellate trophozoite forms. The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade the 
nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the 
meninges. Incubation period is 2 days to 2 weeks. Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B. Options B & D: Both Acanthamoeba and B.mandrillaris cause granulomatous amoebic 
meningoencephalitis which is a subacute condition. Option C: A. cantonensis is the most common cause of eosinophilic meningitis in Southeast Asia. 
It is a nematode(roundworm).

questions.question:
Question 7: A college student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and corneal ulcers 
following the use of contact lens. The saline mount preparation of the corneal scraping shows 
polygonal cysts. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts are suggestive of amoebic 
keratitis caused by acanthamoeba. Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is a free-living amoeba. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant 
cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by 
spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts, or 
directly through traumatized skin or eyes. 522 
Sold by @itachibot It presents as two chronic conditions- acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic 
encephalitis. Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by 
wet mount, histology, and culture. The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis. The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small 
intestine?
questions.explanation:
Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in 
the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum. 523 
Sold by @itachibot Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are 
present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include: • Isospora belli • Cyclospora cayetanensis • Cryptosporidium parvum • Sarcocystis hominis Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large 
intestine. Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica. 524 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. The 
histopathology of the ■duodenum is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis? 508 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the histopathology showing trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the 
duodenal wall is suggestive of giardiasis. Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only 
common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans. Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food and 
is transmitted by the faeco-oral route. 525 
Sold by @itachibot It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the 
infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemic, or 
malnourished individuals. Clinical features: • Diarrhea • Fat malabsorption • Dull epigastric pain • Belching and flatulence • Iron deficiency and growth stunting. • Stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood. Detection of antigen by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test is also 
used in the diagnosis. Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with 
two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy 
infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates. Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents in the treatment. The image given below shows a magnified view of the pear-shaped trophozoites of Giardia 
lamblia.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient is undergoing the test depicted in the image given below. Which of the following 
diseases does it help to diagnose?
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts a string test or entero test and is used in the diagnosis of giardiasis. It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis. 526 
Sold by @itachibot In this test, a coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, 
after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek. The capsule passes through the stomach to 
the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is shaken. The 
centrifuged deposit of the saline is then examined for giardia.

questions.question:
Question 11: The findings of the microscopic examination of the wet mount preparation of stool of a 
patient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which of the following organisms will exhibit this type 
of motility?
questions.explanation:
The given wet mount preparation of stool shows organisms having falling leaf motility. It is 
exhibited by Giardia lamblia. The trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its long axis resembling a falling leaf.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal 
discharge and intense itching. The per speculum finding is given below. Which of the 
following statements is false regarding the causative organism of this disease? 510 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It exists in cyst and trophozoite form
options.c: The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing strawberry cervix is suggestive of Trichomonas 
vaginalis infection. It exists only in trophozoite form. Trichomonas vaginalis is the only protozoan with one stage in its life cycle ie., trophozoite form 
(no cyst stage is seen). It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with 
vaginal, urethral or prostatic tissues. The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, and 
dysuria. The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM (cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose) or 
PEM (plastic envelope medium). The treatment of choice is metronidazole. T. vaginalis infection in women may lead to infertility, preterm birth and low-birth-weight infants. 
In men, trichomoniasis has been also associated with infertility through inflammatory damage to 
the genitourinary tract or interference with sperm function. The below image shows the trophozoite form of Trichomonas vaginalis. 527 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 months. On 
examination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly and 
lymphadenopathy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by T. cruzi. Reduviid bugs are vectors for Chagas disease. Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the 
eye is called Romana’s sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4 
months. The following image shows a patient with Romana's sign. Acute Chagas disease is also characterised by the presence of chagomas which are subcutaneous 
lesions occurring at the site of inoculation. Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy. Shown below is an image of the Reduviid bug. 529 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
questions.explanation:
NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie and 
cruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania. The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie's 
medium. Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig’s medium and NIH polygenic medium 
are used for the culture of E.histolytica.

questions.question: Question 17: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi. T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are 
intracellular parasites. It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man and the intermediate host 
(vector) is reduviid bug or triatomine bugs. Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid 
bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wound on the surface of the 
skin are contaminated by feces of the bug. Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The 
amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then 
released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stage for triatomine bug. No multiplication 
occurs in this stage. Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then 
into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgut which are excreted in feces. 530 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania spp. and hence they are frequently known as 
Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, and reticuloendothelial 
system.

questions.question:
Question 18: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? 513 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given life cycle belongs to Leishmania donovani. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female 
sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. L. donovani exists in 2 forms: • Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals • Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host 
dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It 
is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells. It 
contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is 
absent. Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. 
The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the 
infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans. 531 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: You are performing the following diagnostic procedure in a patient having fever for the past 2 
weeks to find the causative organism. Which disease are you most likely testing for?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows bone marrow aspiration and it is most commonly done to diagnose 
Kala-azar. The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes from bone marrow is the gold standard for the 
diagnosis of Kala-azar Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 
3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Other samples collected are peripheral blood, splenic aspirate, and enlarged lymph node. In kala-azar: • Most common specimen collected for microscopy- bone marrow aspirate. • Most sensitive method- splenic aspirate. Option B: Schistosomiasis is typically diagnosed by stool examination for parasite eggs. Option C: Toxoplasmosis is usually diagnosed based on serologic testing. Option D: Chagas disease is diagnosed by peripheral blood smear examination, culture and 
examination of aspirates from lymph nodes and chagoma.

questions.question: Question 20: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.explanation:
The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. 
The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly. Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus 
and small rod-like kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage. 532 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A 15-year-old boy from Delhi presented to the OPD with the finding seen in the image. It is 
diagnosed to be an oriental sore. Which of the following causes this? 515 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows cutaneous leishmaniasis and is caused by Leishmania tropica complex. It 
is also called oriental sore/Delhi boil/Bagdad boil/Aleppo button. It is seen mainly among children 
in endemic areas. Old world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species: • L. tropica • L. major • L. aethiopica New world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species: • L. mexicana complex • L. braziliensis complex It begins as a raised papule that grows into a nodule which then ulcerates over some 
weeks. The margins of the ulcer are raised and indurated. The ulcer is usually painless unless 
secondary bacterial infection occurs.

questions.question:
Question 22: A medicine resident is evaluating a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The stool wet 
mount finding is given below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli. Living trophozoites/cysts are 
yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount. Balantidium coli occurs in two stages: • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the 
entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is 
broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there 
is a small anal pore (cytopyge). • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

questions.question: Question 23: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar?
questions.explanation:
The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar. The following tests are used for the laboratory diagnosis of kala-azar: • Rapid diagnostic tests - rK39 and dipstick test strip. • Parasitological diagnosis - demonstration of LD bodies on microscopy is confirmatory • Surveillance purposes - Aldehyde test of Napier 533 
Sold by @itachibot • Serological diagnosis - Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent 
antibody test • Assessing immune status - Leishmanin (Montenegro) test • Induration of  5 mm is considered positive • Usually becomes positive 4-6 weeks after onset of cutaneous leishmaniasis 534 
Sold by @itachibot Protozoology - Sporozoa
